item.title: Covid-19: Daily tests to avoid isolation expanded in England
item.description: Police, transport, freight and fire workers will now join the daily contact testing scheme.

item.title: Met Office storm warning for campsites and caravans
item.description: Thunderstorms and 55mph gusts of wind could disrupt the plans of holidaymakers, the Met Office says.

item.title: Concern mounts for missing 11-year-old schoolgirl from Bolton
item.description: The parents of Fatuma Kadir, who travelled from Manchester to London by train, say they are in "shock".

item.title: Latitude festival: Magical, emotional... and a little bit frightening
item.description: Bands and fans describe the atmosphere at the UK's first full-capacity festival since 2019.

item.title: Covid-19: More testing sites and PM faces isolation pressure
item.description: Five things you need to know about the coronavirus pandemic this Saturday evening.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Helen Glover 'has fight on her hands' to retain rowing title
item.description: Team GB's Helen Glover "has a fight on her hands" to win her third rowing Olympic gold medal after a disappointing display in Tokyo.

item.title: Covid-19: Sadiq Khan urges PM to change isolation rules earlier
item.description: Fully vaccinated people should avoid quarantine now by testing daily, the Mayor of London says.

item.title: Surfside tower collapse: No sign of final victim as Miami search ends
item.description: As the search for remains in the collapsed apartment block ends, one victim remains unaccounted for.

item.title: Covid-19: Air travel takes off on busiest weekend since pandemic
item.description: As school holidays begin for many, the airline industry says tens of thousands are flying abroad.

item.title: Jeff Bezos and Sir Richard Branson not yet astronauts, US says
item.description: The US government has tightened rules on which space-goers can claim their astronaut wings.

item.title: Marcus Smith: British and Irish Lions angered by 'offensive' slur on Irish Independent podcast
item.description: The British and Irish Lions and Harlequins both express anger over former Ireland international Neil Francis' description of fly-half Marcus Smith.

item.title: Baby orca, Toa, dies in New Zealand after failed search for mother
item.description: Toa, a killer whale stranded from his family, had washed ashore on the New Zealand coast.

item.title: The young imam using Instagram to change opinions
item.description: Sabah Ahmedi wants to show imams can "have a laugh", have "a bit of banter" and "wear colourful socks".

item.title: The Papers: Pingdemic 'to last weeks' and healthy 'rewards' planned
item.description: Several of Saturday's papers also carry images of the opening ceremony of the Tokyo Olympic Games.

item.title: Scarborough hotel owner couple helping homeless people
item.description: Jess and Andrew Waggitt opened their doors to vulnerable people during the pandemic and continue to do so.

item.title: Tips from the Netherlands on how to build a nation of cyclists
item.description: Some tips from the Dutch Cycling Embassy on how to make bikes the easiest and safest way to travel.

item.title: 'People have never seen anything like this before'
item.description: Live-streamed footage of a family of blue tits has had more than 41 million views online.

item.title: US fires: Inside a US fire truck driving through a wildfire
item.description: As burning ash pelts their vehicle, video shows firefighters in California drive through the flames.

item.title: Week in pictures: 17-23 July 2021
item.description: A selection of powerful images taken around the world this week.

item.title: Makina: the UK subculture you've probably never heard of
item.description: A leading MC says the music genre's return after Covid is going to be "something special".

item.title: Latitude Festival: 'It's so nice to get back into the festival vibe'
item.description: About 40,000 people are expected at this year's Latitude Festival each day.

item.title: Old: Critics split on M Night Shyamalan's new thriller
item.description: Old, the new film from M Night Shyamalan, sees the characters start to age at rapid speed.

item.title: Covid: The holiday makers having to self-isolate abroad
item.description: Some holidaymakers who tested positive for Covid while abroad are having to stay and self-isolate.

item.title: Covid vaccines: Why a giant plastic bag shortage is slowing the rollout
item.description: A look at the critical vaccine components in short supply, as a new global marketplace is launched to tackle bottlenecks.

item.title: Ethiopia's Tigray crisis: What's stopping aid getting in?
item.description: A renewed surge in fighting has made it ever more difficult for aid to reach areas in desperate need.

item.title: Escape to Victory: The Ipswich footballers who made a cult classic
item.description: How did a group of Ipswich Town players end up starring in a film with Pele, Stallone and Caine?

item.title: Clubbing and Covid passports: 'Protect vulnerable people' or 'against civil liberties'?
item.description: Radio 1 Newsbeat chats to clubbers about having to have two jabs to go clubbing.

item.title: Face palm: When the emoji you want doesn't exist
item.description: There are about 3,000 emojis to choose from but what happens when the one you want isn't there?

item.title: Climate change, a coalmine and a town that needs jobs
item.description: In Cumbria, environmental concerns come into conflict with economic hopes.

item.title: Parents' fears over sexting and abuse among teenagers
item.description: A mother and a father reveal their shock at learning of their children's experiences of online sex.

item.title: Sarm Heslop: Missing woman's parents still have hope
item.description: Four months after she vanished, it is still not known what happened to Sarm Heslop.

item.title: Coronavirus: Was US money used to fund risky research in China?
item.description: What's the row about virus research in China between a prominent Republican and Dr Anthony Fauci?

item.title: What are the Delta, Gamma, Beta and Alpha Covid variants?
item.description: UK coronavirus cases are rising due to a variant first identified in India that spreads more easily.

item.title: Trading sex for cosmetic surgery in Mexico's narco capital
item.description: The influence of narcos has caused many women to undergo cosmetic surgery in Mexico's Sinaloa state.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Katarina Johnson-Thompson's battles with injury & self-doubt in pursuit of gold
item.description: How Katarina Johnson-Thompson tore up everything to claim world gold and will have to upset the odds once more to win in Tokyo.

item.title: What does a future-proofed home look like?
item.description: The technology exists to make homes more resilient to extreme weather, but it can be expensive.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Japanese artists reimagine countries as anime samurai
item.description: The creators have used the flags of competing nations as inspiration to design Japanese warriors.

item.title: Amy Winehouse: Could there be new music on the way?
item.description: Ten years after her death, Amy's parents say they want fans to hear CDs of her unreleased material.

item.title: 'I thought rape isn't something that happens to men'
item.description: Support charities say male victims of sexual assault sometimes feel their experiences don't count.

item.title: Eating disorders: The terrible impact of the pandemic on the young
item.description: Admissions soared during the pandemic, and NHS bosses warn they are running out of beds.

item.title: Post Office scandal: What the Horizon saga is all about
item.description: The background to the cases of sub-postmasters whose convictions were based on evidence from faulty IT.

item.title: Murray and Salisbury through in doubles in Tokyo but Watson goes out
item.description: Andy Murray and Joe Salisbury go through in the men's doubles but Heather Watson loses in the first round of the women's singles.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Team GB's Max Whitlock advances to Pommel Horse final
item.description: Team GB's Max Whitlock advances to the Pommel Horse final after earning a 14.9 for his routine.

item.title: 'South Africa are going to be superhuman' - Lions face huge challenge in first Test
item.description: The British and Irish Lions prepare to face a South Africa side driven to provide hope for their country.

item.title: Geraint Thomas: Team GB cyclist crashes in Tokyo Olympics road race
item.description: Watch as Team GB cyclists Geraint Thomas and Tao Geoghegan Hart crash in the men's road race on day one of the Tokyo Olympics- Britain's Tao Geoghegan Hart also involved.

item.title: The Hundred - Birmingham Phoenix v London Spirit: Plays of the day
item.description: Watch the best moments of the women's and men's Hundred matches at Edgbaston as Birmingham Phoenix hosted London Spirit.

item.title: Jadon Sancho: Is right or left wing his best Man Utd position? Or a liberator for Fernandes?
item.description: What clues does Jadon Sancho's Borussia Dortmund career give us about how he will fit in at Manchester United?

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Medals Table
item.description: Medals table for the 2020 Olympics in Tokyo.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Helen Glover and Polly Swann battle into semi-finals, Andy Murray and Joe Salisbury win
item.description: A shaky start for Helen Glover and Polly Swann but Andy Murray and Joe Salisbury win doubles opener.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: First gold of Games goes to China's Yang Qian in shooting
item.description: Chinese shooter Yang Qian wins the first gold of the Olympics but has to sing her anthem behind a mask and hang her own medal round her neck.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Table tennis 12-year-old Hend Zaza, gymnast Zou Jingyuan and 3x3 basketball - best moments
item.description: Watch some of the best moments from the opening events of the Tokyo Olympics including a 12-year-old table tennis player and debut of 3x3 basketball.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Syria's Hend Zaza, 12, is out, but hopes to inspire others
item.description: Youngest Olympian Hend Zaza, the 12-year-old Syrian table tennis star, wants to inspire others despite losing 4-0 in the preliminary round.

item.title: Tokyo 2020: How well do you know Olympic sports lingo?
item.description: Ever heard of a guppy hold? Know which sport would see a pancake used? Test how good your knowledge of Olympic lingo is.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Day-by-day guide to the key events, big stars and British medal hopes
item.description: Want to know what's happening when in Tokyo? Check out our comprehensive guide to all the action in Japan.

item.title: Polly Swann: Olympic rower on working the wards, training in her shed & unfinished business
item.description: BBC Scotland speaks to Olympic rower Polly Swann on juggling training for Tokyo with working in a surgical ward in the midst of the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Watch best opening ceremony moments in two minutes
item.description: Watch all the best bits from the Tokyo 2020 opening ceremony - including the best of the athletes' entrances and the lighting of the iconic Olympic flame by Naomi Osaka.

item.title: Team GB athletics - who are the medal hopes?
item.description: Who are Great Britain's big hopes and long shots to get on the podium in Tokyo? London 2012 Olympian and former world silver medallist Hannah England gives her view...

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Jamaican sprinter Shelly-Ann Fraser-Pryce trying to reach 'great things'
item.description: Jamaican sprinter and two-time Olympic gold medallist Shelly-Ann Fraser-Pryce aims to get to the "great things" at Tokyo 2020.

item.title: 'What a sight!' - Drones light up above Olympic stadium
item.description: Watch as the sky above Japan's Olympic Stadium is illuminated by 1,800 drones for the opening ceremony of the Tokyo 2020 Olympics.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Team GB enter the opening ceremony in Tokyo
item.description: Watch as Team GB enter the Olympic opening ceremony for Tokyo 2020, led by joint flagbearers Hannah Mills and Mohamed Sbihi.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Dina Asher-Smith opens up on body image & tackling racism in sport
item.description: Dina Asher-Smith opens up about life on and off the track with friend and Radio 1 DJ Clara Amfo.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: BBC TV schedule, radio and online coverage - times and channels
item.description: Full listings and coverage channels for the Tokyo Olympics across BBC TV, BBC iPlayer, BBC radio and online.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Ten tear-jerking moments from the Olympics past
item.description: It isn't always the big names and blue-riband events that create all the memories. Here are 10 times the Olympics has set spines tingling and tears flowing

item.title: Olympic football: Men's players to watch at Tokyo 2020
item.description: Here is the lowdown on the biggest names and brightest stars looking to shine this summer in the men's Olympic football tournament.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Katie Archibald on her gold medal dreams & pressure
item.description: Cyclist Katie Archibald tells BBC Sport about her dreams of another gold medal and the pressure of helping Laura Kenny become Britain's best.

item.title: Tokyo 2020: Top 10 days for Team GB at the Olympics
item.description: BBC Sport selects the top 10 unmissable days for Team GB fans at the Tokyo 2020 Olympics.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics opening ceremony: Hannah Mills and rower Mohamed Sbihi to be Team GB flag bearers
item.description: Sailor Hannah Mills and rower Mohamed Sbihi are chosen to carry the flag for Great Britain at Friday's Tokyo Olympics opening ceremony.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: How quiet rebel Naomi Osaka is changing Japan
item.description: Naomi Osaka's relationship with Japan has not always been easy, but change rarely is. How the face of the Games is changing the host nation.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid: What do under-30s need to know about the vaccine?
item.description: All over-18s can now get the Covid jab, but the government has criticised take-up among young people.

item.title: What are the rules and guidance for face masks and coverings from 19 July?
item.description: Masks are no longer compulsory in England, but remain necessary in Scotland and Wales.

item.title: Long Covid: What is it and what are the symptoms?
item.description: New research links as many as 200 different symptoms to the condition.

item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the virus has spread around the world.

item.title: Tokyo Olympic Games: When are they and how will Covid affect them?
item.description: The Tokyo Summer Olympics have begun, despite a surge in Covid cases in Japan.

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The progress made in vaccinating the country's adult population, as more than 46 million people have received at least one dose.

item.title: Covid: Who has to self-isolate, which workers are exempt and what if I'm fully vaccinated?
item.description: A small number of named employees in key sectors will be exempt from some rules

item.title: Care homes worst hit by Covid – search the data
item.description: Figures from Care Quality Commission lay out the pandemic's 'devastating impact' on care homes in England.

item.title: Covid symptoms: Is it a cold or coronavirus?
item.description: With similar symptoms, deciding whether or not you need to get tested for coronavirus can be tricky.

item.title: Coronavirus: How does the NHS test-and-trace system and app work?
item.description: The contact tracing app could be changed to make it less sensitive, so it sends fewer alerts.

item.title: Covid rules from 19 July: What has changed?
item.description: Major changes to lockdown rules have taken effect in England and Scotland, but some restrictions remain.

item.title: Covid: Why is social distancing coming to an end?
item.description: Social distancing rules are changing across the UK.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: Vaccine experts recommend that a limited group of children should be offered Covid jabs ahead of winter.

item.description: Clubbers and people attending mass events in England will have to prove they've had both Covid jabs.

item.description: There are fears that this version of coronavirus, first identified in South Africa, is

item.title: What are the rules for travelling to green, amber and red list countries?
item.description: Fully jabbed adults don't have to self-isolate after visiting amber-list countries - except France.

item.title: Covid: Which children are being vaccinated and why?
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of children at higher risk from coronavirus infection will be offered a Covid vaccine in the UK.

item.title: What are the travel rules for Spain, Portugal, Malta and other holiday hotspots?
item.description: What you need to know about going to Portugal, Spain, Greece, France, Malta, Italy and Turkey.

item.title: Covid-19: Five ways to avoid catching the virus indoors
item.description: As social distancing restrictions end in England and ease in Scotland, good ventilation remains vital.

item.title: The EU vaccine 'passport' and what it means for travel
item.description: An EU vaccine "passport" is being introduced, enabling holders to prove they have been jabbed.

item.title: Coronavirus cure: What progress are we making on treatments?
item.description: Medical teams around the world are learning which medicines work best against Covid.
